Sure, here are some possible ways to streamline the process of attaching promotion workflows to Artifact CIs:

1. Drag-and-drop interface: You could create a drag-and-drop interface that allows users to easily assign a promotion workflow to multiple Artifact CIs at once. For example, users could select the promotion workflow they want to assign from a list, and then drag it onto a group of Artifact CIs that they want to assign it to. This would allow users to quickly and easily assign promotion workflows to multiple Artifact CIs without having to manually edit each one.
2. Bulk edit feature: Another option is to create a bulk edit feature that allows users to select multiple Artifact CIs and assign the same promotion workflow to all of them at once. This could be done using checkboxes or a similar selection mechanism, where users can select the Artifact CIs they want to edit and then choose the promotion workflow to assign to them. This would also allow users to quickly and easily assign promotion workflows to multiple Artifact CIs at once.
3. Default promotion workflows: You could provide default promotion workflows for common use cases, such as promoting from development to production. This would save users time and effort, as they wouldn't need to create a new promotion workflow every time they want to promote a build. Users could still customize the promotion workflows as needed, but having default templates would make the process faster and easier.
4. Automated promotion: Another option is to automate the promotion process entirely, so that builds are automatically promoted from one environment to another based on predefined rules. This would eliminate the need for users to manually assign promotion workflows to Artifact CIs, and would ensure that builds are always promoted in a consistent and controlled manner. However, this approach may not be suitable for all organizations, depending on their specific requirements and workflows.
